awd_abstract_narration:
Density surrogates are quantities that can help measure the likelihood of seeing observations with certain characteristics. This project aims at developing novel statistical approaches based on density surrogates and analyzing the underlying theoretical properties. Methodologies developed from this project will be applied to solving scientific questions such as investigating human activities using GPS data and detecting matter distribution inside our Universe.

This project focuses on developing new statistical methodologies for analyzing complex data sets using density surrogates. Density surrogates are quantities similar to the probability density that characterizes the underlying distribution of the observed random sample. Examples of density surrogates include the linkage criterion in a hierarchical clustering, radius of the k-nearest neighborhood, and expected value of a kernel density estimator. This project proposes several novel density surrogates and designs new statistical tools. These new density surrogates can be used to perform statistical analysis in situations where the conventional density-based approaches fail.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on developing new statistical methodologies for analyzing complex datasets using density surrogates. Density surrogates are quantities similar to the probability density that characterizes the underlying distribution of the observed random sample. Examples of density surrogates include the linkage criterion in a hierarchical clustering, radius of the k-nearest neighborhood, and expected value of a kernel density estimator. This project proposes several novel density surrogates and designs new statistical tools. These new density surrogates can be used to perform statistical analysis in situations where the conventional density-based approaches fail. We have obtained fruitful results from this project. 10 research papers have been published in leading statistical journals. Here are some highlights of key findings. 

In Generalized Cluster Trees and Singular Measures, we study the problem of detecting high-density regions when the data may be coming from different "dimensional structures". Later in Measuring Human Activity Spaces from GPS Data with Density Ranking and Summary Curves, we apply the developed techniques to the GPS data and show that this new method reveals meaningful structures in the GPS data.
With the support of this project, we also developed two novel clustering methods. In Refined Mode-Clustering via the Gradient of Slope, we design a clustering algorithm that outputs a cluster with an attribute label and show that the attribute label provides useful information about the associated cluster. In Skeleton Clustering: Dimension-Free Density-based Clustering, we introduce a new concept called skeleton -- a graph where vertices indicate landmark locations in the data and edges represent the connectivity among landmarks. We use the skeleton to cluster the data into groups and we show the potential of applying this procedure to complex data scenarios. 
Moreover, the support of this project also leads us to study the estimation problem in directional data. The directional data is the scenario where observations represent angles or latitude/longitude on a sphere. The directional nature makes the data analysis much more challenging than a conventional problem. In Kernel Smoothing, Mean Shift, and Their Learning Theory with Directional Data, we study the problem of estimating a probability density and its gradient flow in the directional data. We generalize a famous method called the mean-shift algorithm to directional data and derive its statistical and numerical properties.
This project has broader impacts on Astronomy research. With the support of this project, the PI collaborated with Astronomers and discover new pheonomona of the so-called "large-scale structures" in our Universe. In Detecting Galaxy-Filament Alignments in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III, we obtain evidences for how the shape of a galaxy is influenced by its nearby cosmic webs. In Alignment between filaments and galaxy spins from the MaNGA integral-field survey, we further investigate how the spin axis of a galaxy is shaped by the cosmic webs.
